instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Hello. Got this board here. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.23V, which means SMC is not talking to ISL. Replaced ISL and SMC but still same results. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is not present. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is steady 3.3V. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is steady 3.42V. I get no green light on charger eve though <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> is steady 3.42V. Tried replacing magsafe board with known good one, still same. I'm stuck now. I'm sure this SMC chip I soldered is good because it was negotiating 12.56V on the donor board I took it from(donor board got bad PCH). What else can I check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Do you get 12MHz at Y5010?
Check power rails and signals for <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> ( 2 OF 2) at page 45.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Hello.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> - 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

Replaced Y5010 just in case as I don't have oscilloscope to measure its clock signal. Same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: There was a broken trace between <RESISTOR>R5010</RESISTOR> and SMC. Ran a wire and now I get green light and 12.56V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, but still no power. S4 rails are not activating.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Let the board cool down and now it's working. Thanks for the help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
For the future, if you cannot control the frequency with o-scope, or frequency meter, check DC voltage at crystal pins at least.
You will find 1-1.2V DC for working crystal, on both pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Just now i am working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Sus o/p signal from pch is missing. <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is getting generated but <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is missing. Tracing the signal i find <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is missing. What should i check in PCH. ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Please, stop hijacking other threads.
Open new thread with your 3115 board problem.
